title.rendered: Abrams for Governor Observes Earth Day, Announces Georgia Conservation Voters Endorsement and Releases New Video Highlighting Climate Concerns of Young Georgians

content.rendered:
ATLANTA – Today, Abrams for Governor joined Georgians across the state in observing Earth Day, announced a new endorsement from Georgia Conservation Voters Action Fund and released a new video highlighting the climate concerns of young Georgians.

“On this day when we celebrate our Earth and recommit to its protection, I am honored to receive the endorsement of the Georgia Conservation Voters Action Fund,” said Stacey Abrams. “GCV gives a voice to climate voters across Georgia, especially young people who have the most to lose if we as a state, nation and world fail to collectively act. Each year, as temperatures and sea levels rise, the significance of Earth Day also heightens. Georgia’s shores and waterways are at risk. Communities across the state have repeatedly suffered through hurricanes, tornadoes and storms intensified by climate change. 

As the next governor of Georgia, I will both address the urgency and harness the opportunities this global crisis affords. My environmental action plan will generate significant job growth through advanced energy generation, innovative technologies and energy efficiency efforts. 

Together, as One Georgia, we will work to preserve the environment in our state and ensure a brighter and more secure future for all Georgians.”

In addition to proposing an ambitious environmental action plan, Abrams has a track record of supporting eco-friendly legislation that protects and preserves Georgia’s environment. During her 11 years in office, Abrams consistently sponsored or voted for clean energy, public participation and protections, renewable energy expansion, low emission vehicles credits, and clean water protection. Outside of her work in the legislature, Abrams used her small business skills to co-found Insomnia Consulting, which specializes in development, investment and consulting for complex infrastructure projects, including transportation, energy, facilities and water. Abrams served on the advisory board of Climate Power and was an original member of World War Zero, led by now-U.S. Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry, a bipartisan coalition that aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. One of her first roles in public service was for the Environmental Protection Agency in the then-new Office of Environmental Justice during the Clinton Administration. She served as Executive Director of the Southern Economic Advancement Project, which issued a climate report for the South and a survey showing Southern voters’ concerns about climate change.

Abrams for Governor also released a video of young Georgians voicing their concerns about the climate crisis and the need for Stacey to be the next governor of Georgia.

Abrams’ detailed plan to protect the planet and fight climate change can be found on her website at staceyabrams.com/policy/#environmental-action.

Further reading: 
Grist: Stacey Abrams helped Georgia go blue. Now she wants it to go green.
Abrams op-ed: Leaders Must Learn The Lessons Of COVID In Time To Fight Climate Change
